bestBHT.bht: To abide in the flesh, to continue somewhat longer, is more needful for you. Paul's deep love and concern for the Philippians lead him to prioritize remaining in his physical body, even though he is longing for the joys of heaven. He understands the value of his continued presence for the church, as he can still offer his experience, influence, and counsel. Paul recognizes that God has more work for him to accomplish, and by staying alive, he can continue to serve and glorify Christ, benefiting the lives of believers.

Henry Alford: 24.] but to continue in my flesh is more needful on account of you (and others—but the expressions of his love are now directed solely to them).
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: heaven will not fail to be mine at last.
Albert Barnes: Nevertheless to abide in the flesh - To live. All this is language derived from the belief that the soul will be separate from the body at death, and will occupy a separate state of existence.
He never supposed that his life was useless; or that it was a matter of no importance to the cause of religion whether he lived or died.

His experience, his influence, his paternal counsels, he felt assured would be of value to the church, and he had, therefore, a desire to live - and it was no part of his religion affectedly to undervalue or despise himself.
Marvin Vincent: To abide in the flesh [επιμενειν εν τη σαρκι] . See on Colossians 1:23. To abide by the flesh. Compare Romans 6:1; Romans 11:22, Romans 11:23.
Philip Schaff: He sees that there is much which lies before him, which God is showing that he would have him do."
The sense that the churches will be the better for his life, and need his continued care.
It brings with it the certainty that God will not yet call him home.
Archibald T. Robertson: Unnecessary with επιμενω, to abide by (common verb)."
So B D G, but Aleph A C do not have εν.
John Gill: To abide in the flesh,.... To continue in the body, not always, but a little longer, is more needful for you.
The argument for living longer on consideration of glorifying Christ, and of being more useful to the good of souls, preponderated with him.
Like a brave and good man, he prefers a public good to a private one.

bhtAttempts.bht: To abide in the flesh is more needful on account of you. Paul acknowledges that while he is longing for heaven, he recognizes the importance of remaining in his physical body for the sake of the Philippians and others. He understands that his continued presence is beneficial for the church, as he can still offer his experience, influence, and counsel. Paul sees the work that God still has for him to accomplish and the impact he can have on the lives of believers. Despite his desire for heaven, Paul chooses to prioritize the greater good of serving and glorifying Christ by being more useful to the church and the souls of others.

To abide in the flesh is more needful for you. Paul acknowledges the importance of remaining in his physical body for the sake of the Philippians and others. He understands that his continued presence is beneficial for the church, as he can still offer his experience, influence, and counsel. Paul sees the work that God still has for him to accomplish and the impact he can have on the lives of believers. Despite his desire for heaven, Paul chooses to prioritize the greater good of serving and glorifying Christ.

To continue in my flesh is more needful on account of you. Paul's love and concern for the Philippians lead him to prioritize remaining in his physical body, even though he longs for the eternal joy of heaven. He recognizes that his presence is valuable for the church, as he can still offer his experience, influence, and guidance. Paul is convinced that there is still work to be done, and by staying alive, he can continue to glorify Christ and be of service to the believers.

Paul's selfless love for the Philippians prompts him to prioritize remaining in his physical body, acknowledging that his presence is more important for their sake. Though he longs for the joys of heaven, he understands that his continued life is necessary for the benefit of the church. By staying alive, Paul can continue to offer his experience, influence, and guidance. He recognizes the work that God still has for him to accomplish and the impact he can have on the lives of believers, so he willingly chooses to prioritize serving and glorifying Christ.

To abide in the flesh, to continue somewhat longer, is more needful for you. Paul's deep love and concern for the Philippians lead him to prioritize remaining in his physical body, even though he is longing for the joys of heaven. He understands the value of his continued presence for the church, as he can still offer his experience, influence, and counsel. Paul recognizes that God has more work for him to accomplish, and by staying alive, he can continue to serve and glorify Christ, benefiting the lives of believers.
